hints.content: Start by initializing an empty result string. This will be used to build the final output as you process each character in the input string.
Remember to iterate through each character in the string `s`. Use a loop to access each character one by one.
When you encounter a lowercase letter, simply append it to your result string. For example, if you encounter 'a', your result should become 'a'.
Consider how to handle the '*' character. It should remove the last character from the result string. Make sure to check if the result is not empty before trying to remove a character.
The '#' character duplicates the current result. Think about how you can concatenate the result with itself. For instance, if your result is 'abc', after this operation it should be 'abcabc'.
When you see the '%' character, you need to reverse the current result. You can use string slicing or a built-in function to achieve this easily.
Pay attention to the order of operations. Each character should be processed in the order they appear in the string, from left to right.
Consider edge cases, such as what happens when '*' is encountered with an empty result or when '#' is applied to an empty string. Ensure your code handles these situations gracefully.
Make sure to test your implementation with various inputs, especially edge cases like strings that only contain special characters or are very short.
Finally, after processing all characters in the string, return the result. Ensure that your function returns the final string correctly.

questionNotes: s consists of only lowercase English letters and special characters: *, #, and %
The operations must be processed in the order they appear in the input string.
